title: The Saga of Ryanair Flight 4978
description: Why did the leader of Belarus force a commercial airplane to land? Who was he after? And what might happen next?
content: Last week, when the pilots on a commercial flight headed for Lithuania told passengers they were about to make an unexpected landing in the Belarusian capital of Minsk many were confused — except Roman Protasevich.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: A Writer’s One-Act Plays Debut, Continuing Her Resurrection
description: By staging Kathleen Collins’s rich psychological portraits of Black women, a theatrical group aims to enlighten, heal and inspire.
content: “No one is going to mythologize my life,” the playwright and filmmaker Kathleen Collins said in 1984 to a group of film students at Howard University. “No one is going to refuse me the right to explore my experiences of life as normal experiences.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: As U.S. vaccinations slump, CVS offers cruises, money and a Super Bowl trip to get a shot.
description: The prizes are part of a wave of incentives to persuade the unvaccinated to go to pharmacies to get their shots.
content: Facing a national decline in Covid-19 vaccination rates and an underwhelming response to vaccines in its own stores, the U.S. pharmacy chain CVS will offer a chance at money, vacations and a Super Bowl trip to persuade the unvaccinated to start going in for their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Mike Faist Isn’t Sure About This Whole Acting Thing
description: “I can’t tell if I hate acting or if I love it too much,” he said ahead of the debut of the Amazon series “Panic.” Coming soon, a major role in Steven Spielberg’s “West Side Story.” For now, he’s going to Ohio.
content: Tall and lanky, looking as if he were born wearing Wranglers, Mike Faist cuts quite a striking figure in the Amazon Prime series “Panic”: His character, Dodge Mason, is a Stetson-wearing rodeo dude who breaks untamed horses, then soulfully gazes into their eyes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve M. Kahn
title: MoMA Built a House. Then It Disappeared. Now It’s Found.
description: In 1950, the museum exhibited Gregory Ain’s modernist creation. It’s now nestled in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.
content: CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — In 1950, a glass-walled house, now nestled amid flowering trees here, spent a few months in Manhattan. Skyscrapers loomed over its flat roof while it was on exhibit in the Museum of Modern Art’s garden. The installation, designed by the architect Gregory Ain and co-sponsored with Woman’s Home Companion magazine, was meant to inspire creativity on a budget for residential subdivisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Wilson
title: Overlooked No More: Si-lan Chen, Whose Dances Encompassed Worlds
description: As a dancer and choreographer, she sought to represent a broad range of ethnic groups, but audiences often sexualized and exoticized her by focusing on her mixed race.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Hoberman
title: ‘Her Man’: A Relic of a Bygone Hollywood, Now Restored
description: Now streaming, this mildly racy romance, from 1930, arrived before the censorious Production Code. What really sets the film apart is its incredible tracking shots.
content: “Her Man,” a snappy bit of hokum inspired by the venerable crime-of-passion ballad “Frankie and Johnny,” was well received when it arrived in 1930. Decades later, the mildly racy romance, with lightly disguised hookers and pimps, would become a bone of contention between critics conversant with classic Hollywood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Restaurant Openings and Moves Across the Hamptons
description: Newcomers and updates from long-lived spots, from Southampton to Montauk.
content: For those who inhabit or visit the South Fork of Eastern Long Island, the Hamptons, the high season that begins with Memorial Day inevitably includes a new crop of restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Alvin Bragg for Manhattan D.A.
description: The career crime fighter would keep the public safe without returning to overly punitive practices of the past.
content: There are few bigger jobs on the New York ballot this year than that of Manhattan district attorney. Cyrus Vance Jr., one of only two men who have held the office since 1975, isn’t seeking re-election. In a borough where Democrats vastly outnumber Republicans, the winner of the June 22 primary contest is very likely to cruise to victory in November, and there is a crowded field of talented lawyers who are vying to replace him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: What to Name a Bunch of Black Holes? You Had Some Ideas.
description: Recently, astronomers asked aloud which plural term would best suit the most enigmatic entity in the cosmos. The responses were plentiful.
content: In April, during the fetchingly (or chillingly) titled Black Hole Week, a group of astronomers initiated what amounted to a kind of cosmic Rorschach test.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Juan Williams, a Liberal Outlier at Fox News, Is Leaving ‘The Five’
description: He will continue contributing to the cable network as a senior political analyst based in Washington.
content: The Fox News host Juan Williams said on Wednesday that he was leaving his longtime perch on “The Five,” the weekday afternoon chat show where he had served as the liberal outlier of an otherwise reliably conservative quintet of hosts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Administration to Require Pipeline Companies to Report Cyberattacks
description: The move, which will require companies to report to the government any significant attacks, is a response to the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attacks.
content: The Biden administration will require the nation’s pipeline companies to report to the government any time they are hit with a significant cyberattack, and to create 24-hour emergency centers for such episodes, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the secretary of homeland security, said Thursday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Swimming Out Till the Sea Turns Blue’ Review: China Through Writers’ Eyes
description: Jia Zhangke’s documentary illuminates a vast and complicated history in a series of intimate conversations.
content: The films of Jia Zhangke, documentary and fictional, zoom in on the granular details of individual lives. At the same time, they are chapters in the single, unimaginably complicated story of China’s transformation in the decades since the 1949 revolution. Jia, who was born in 1970, tends to dwell in the recent past, and to circle back to Shanxi, the part of northern China where he grew up, but he’s also attentive to the continuities of history and geography, the connections between generations and places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finbarr O'Reilly and Marc Santora
title: In Congo, Masses Flee One of the World’s Most Dangerous Volcanoes
description: Days after a deadly eruption of Mount Nyiragongo in Democratic Republic of Congo, the threat of another eruption forced the evacuation of much of the city of Goma.
content: GOMA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Tens of thousands of people jammed highways, crowded boats and set off on foot to flee this major African city on Thursday, seeking an escape from the rumbling threat of Mount Nyiragongo, one of the world’s most active and dangerous volcanoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Samuel E. Wright, the Voice of Sebastian in ‘The Little Mermaid,’ Dies at 72
description: Mr. Wright also worked on Broadway, earning a Tony nomination as Mufasa in the original cast of “The Lion King.”
content: Samuel E. Wright, a veteran stage actor who earned two Tony Award nominations but was best known for voicing the headstrong crab Sebastian in the 1989 animated film “The Little Mermaid,” died on Monday at his home in Walden, N.Y. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A new investigation into the coronavirus.
content: President Biden has ordered U.S. intelligence agencies to investigate the origins of the coronavirus, calling for a broad government report on whether the virus was accidentally leaked from a lab in Wuhan, China. He has given them 90 days to report back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: On Voting Rights, Biden Prefers to Negotiate. This Time, It Might Not Be Possible.
description: The president’s long history of deal making on the issue is crashing into the realities of a more sharply partisan time.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden confronts intense Republican opposition to the broad voting rights bill that Democrats have made a top priority this year, he might remember back to 1982 and an earlier partisan clash over the issue, one of a number across the years that shaped his views on deal making — and its limits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Chenin Blanc From Three Places
description: It’s an underrated white grape that flourishes in the Loire Valley and very few other places.
content: Chenin blanc is one of my favorite grapes, with a singular texture and a rare versatility. It’s capable not only of transparently expressing the qualities of different terroirs but of making bone-dry wines, succulently sweet wines and a whole range in between.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Goodbye to a Yankee Farmer, the Ghost of Exit 8
description: In 1964, a Vermont farmer burned himself and his farm, rather than surrender his land. His neighbors can’t let him go.
content: WEATHERSFIELD, Vt. — The morning sun was just slanting through the trees when a crew arrived with chain saws to remove the last sign of Romaine Tenney.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 10 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: The approach of Memorial Day means that a lot of people are nearing the end of a very weird school year — one that started with learning via computer screen and is concluding with a fitful return to something like normal, with proms and in-person graduation ceremonies, masked or not. But the end of school doesn’t need to mean the end of learning. We have a full curriculum of books on offer this week, from geometry (“Shape,” by Jordan Ellenberg) to U.S. history (“King Richard,” by Michael Dobbs) to science (“The Premonition,” by Michael Lewis) to psychology (“Think Again,” by Adam Grant). There’s a music memoir by Brandi Carlile and, in fiction, a collection of updated folk tales as well as novels set in Brazil, Japan, London and New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden pitches his spending plans during a visit to an Ohio community college.
description: The president toured the Cuyahoga Community College Manufacturing Technology Center in Cleveland.
content: President Biden delivered an impassioned speech at a Cleveland community college on Thursday pressing his case for trillions of dollars in spending on infrastructure and improving the social safety net, even as he continued sparring with Republicans in Washington over his proposals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Champions League Is Considering a Final Four in One City
description: The Champions League final is the biggest day on the European soccer calendar. But what if it was a week instead?
content: PORTO, Portugal — Last summer, with the coronavirus raging through Europe, leaders at European soccer’s governing body huddled to find a way to salvage the Champions League, one of the game’s most popular competitions and among its biggest sources of revenue for its elite clubs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: The Disparities in Access to New York’s Parks
description: Low-income residents and people of color have  significantly less  space available to them than residents of white and wealthy areas.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. Says It Will Not Rejoin Open Skies Treaty With Russia
description: The 30-year-old agreement was put in place to ensure that Russia and the United States could monitor each other’s military movements.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has informed Russia that the United States will not rejoin a treaty that allowed the nations to conduct surveillance of each other, even though President Biden harshly criticized his predecessor during last year’s campaign for pulling out of the agreement, State Department officials said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Shawn Hubler and Kellen Browning
title: Gunman Kills 9 People at San Jose Rail Yard
description: The gunman, who apparently killed himself, was an employee of the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority, a regional transit agency for Silicon Valley.
content: SAN JOSE, Calif. — A municipal transit worker opened fire as the Wednesday morning shift was gathering for work at a San Jose rail yard, killing nine people in the latest of the mass shootings that have plagued the United States this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Checking the Tissue After Blowing Your Nose
description: Should we be creeped out by public investigations of our bodily productions?
content: Kristin writes: Every time my fiancé, Gabe, blows his nose, he opens the tissue to inspect it. He claims it’s to ensure his snot looks normal. Please order him to stop, unless he has specific health concerns, like a cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: In ‘Cruella,’ Fashion Is Toxic
description: The new Disney movie is the latest in a long line of Hollywood films that demonizes the industry. Why?
content: There is a scene, about halfway through “Cruella,” the new Disney origin story for the “101 Dalmatians” baddie, in which the Baroness, a fashion designer diva played by Emma Thompson, is sipping Champagne with her new employee — a would-be designer named Estella and played by Emma Stone — and lecturing her on what it takes to succeed in the business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Summer in the City Returns
description: Getting back to people-watching after a tough year, and other suggestions for what to do around the city.
content: Hey! Welcome back to Summer in the City, your weekly one-stop newsletter for all things related to summer fun in New York, from Memorial Day to Labor Day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pennsylvania has a new crop, thanks to the growth of e-commerce.
description: In recent decades, the area in and around Pennsylvania’s Lehigh Valley has evolved from its agricultural and manufacturing roots to also become a health care and higher education hub.
content: In recent decades, the area in and around Pennsylvania’s Lehigh Valley has evolved from its agricultural and manufacturing roots to also become a health care and higher education hub.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Light
title: What Makes a Musical Genius?
description: Books about everything from Tupac Shakur to Latin music and memoirs by Sinead O’Connor and Rickie Lee Jones offer an answer.
content: “There is nothing I could write in this book or tell you that would help you get to know me,” writes Sinead O’Connor in her new memoir, REMEMBERINGS (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 304 pp., $28). “It is all in the songs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Joanna Ho Knows the Virtue of Patience. She’s a High School Vice Principal
description: Her debut picture book is a best seller, but the road to get there wasn’t always easy.
content: NEW VIEW Talking to a writer who has vaulted onto the best-seller list is a bit like listening to an Olympian who has just won a gold medal. There’s a certain celebratory flurry, a dependable repetition of the word “surreal” and, as with an athlete’s appreciation for a coach, an abiding sense of gratitude for the editor and agent who helped lift an author onto this literary podium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Defends Huge Alaska Oil Drilling Project
description: The administration says the country must pivot away from fossil fuels but backed a project set to produce more than 100,000 barrels of oil each day for 30 years.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is defending a huge Trump-era oil and gas project in the North Slope of Alaska designed to produce more than 100,000 barrels of oil a day for the next 30 years, despite President Biden’s pledge to pivot the country away from fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Olivia Waite
title: Sweet, Sexy and Rebellious: Summer’s New Romance Novels
description: Mainstream publishers are fully embracing queer love stories, our columnist writes: “I would call it an embarrassment of riches but what it really is, of course, is pride.”
content: Time was I could have covered every queer romance novel put out by mainstream publishers and still have had room to spare in this column. Small and independent presses have been nurturing L.G.B.T.Q. romance authors forever, and digital self-publishing opened up still more doors, but up until very recently, the big traditional houses had far more queer villains than queer romance leads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Collier and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: Len Bias, a Bouquet of Flowers, and Ms. Brooks
description: A moment between legends.
content: Len Bias dropped buckets in Frederick Douglass’s home state, where I was raised. And it’s startling to find that one night, instead of softly putting that orange globe in the bucket, he was handing flowers to Ms. Gwendolyn Brooks, who was doing a reading at the University of Maryland. Bias stopped by for a second with flowers — Collier reminds us of it all, with this Golden Shovel, borrowing his end words from “she kisses her killed boy,” a line in Brooks’s “The Last Quatrain of a Ballad for Emmett Till,” reminding us that while “it is difficult to get the news from poems ...” Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sebastian Modak
title: New Audiobooks for Your Summer Road Trip
description: From funny women to Yo-Yo Ma, self-reflection to civil rights, there’s something in the queue for everyone.
content: It was only recently that I discovered the joy to be found in an audiobook-fueled road trip. For the longest time, books seemed too evocative for car rides, too absorbing to serve as mere accompaniment to a scenic journey. But then, around two years ago, I found myself in Chile, exhausted by a string of flight delays and facing a long drive through the night. Trusting an algorithm to find something to keep me awake, I downloaded “The Lost City of Z,” David Grann’s gripping tale of the obsessive, swashbuckling Victorian explorer Percy Fawcett.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Vaccine Mandate Unleashes a Mob in a Small Polish Town
description: The mayor of a former mining community in Poland received death threats and was compared to a Nazi death camp doctor after trying to make coronavirus shots obligatory for adults.
content: WALBRZYCH, Poland — The mayor, a heart surgeon, had just finished overnight hospital duty when he received alarming news: a mob of protesters, some dressed in military camouflage, had gathered outside his home, screaming abuse through bullhorns and waving banners comparing him to Josef Mengele, the Nazi death camp physician.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Harvey Schlossberg, Cop With a Ph.D. in Defusing a Crisis, Dies at 85
description: A psychologist who had worn the blue, he coached thousands of New York City police officers in hostage negotiations, creating a model for law enforcement.
content: Harvey Schlossberg, a former New York City traffic cop with a doctorate in psychology who choreographed what became a model law enforcement strategy for safely ending standoffs with hostage takers, died on May 21 in Brooklyn. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Txakolina, a Simple Pleasure With a Deep Sense of Place
description: This slightly effervescent wine of the Spanish Basque Country epitomizes the globalization of once-local wines in the 21st century.
content: To understand the path of wine in the 21st century, consider a bottle of Txakolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson
title: The Benefits of Ordering Dinner From Instagram
description: As restaurants struggled last year, many chefs survived by selling food directly to customers, an age-old practice that is now shaping the future of hospitality.
content: Last September, the chef Jennifer Kim did something that would have been unthinkable a year prior: Faced with the possibility of an ongoing shutdown as cases of Covid-19 rose in Chicago, and the risk of her staff getting sick, she closed the doors of Passerotto, the successful Italian-inflected Korean restaurant she’d opened in the city’s Andersonville neighborhood in 2018. “We had to make the decision to put people over profits,” she said. But she hardly sat idle. Instead, she began offering ready-made dishes and do-it-yourself meal kits, ordered via a website and prepped by herself and others in underground kitchens, shared kitchen spaces and even homes around Chicago. On the day of pickup, Kim and the vendors whose wares were part of the boxes collectively put together the orders in storefronts or restaurants where customers could stop by and take home their food. “The advantage of having no dedicated staff and everyone being their own bosses is that it’s a decentralized, fluid and completely collaborative project,” Kim says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Great Unmasking
description: After Covid, a better life is possible.
content: For millions of Americans, the next six months are going to be great. The power Covid had over our lives is shrinking, and the power we have over our own lives is growing. The image that comes to mind is recess. We’ve been stuck emotionally indoors for over a year. Now we get to sprint down the hallway and burst into the playground of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Blue Miracle’ Review: Fishing Lessons
description: Mexican orphans find hope through a fishing tournament in this cloying underdog Netflix drama.
content: Gratingly sentimental and simplistic, Julio Quintana’s “Blue Miracle,” set in Cabo San Lucas in 2014, turns a potentially compelling underdog tale into a sermon. But if you’re in the mood to see Dennis Quaid learning and growing — and engaging in sappy conversations about fatherhood — then step right up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: A Deep Look at Germany’s Resurgent Far Right
description: “Day X,” a new five-part audio documentary from The Times, examines the rise of a new brand of extremism, and one shadowy figure in the middle of it.
content: Katrin Bennhold was a Times correspondent in London in 2017 when Franco A. was arrested. “I remember hearing about it from afar and thinking how crazy it seemed,” she said. Franco A. was a German military officer who was caught posing as a Syrian refugee and who is now accused of plotting political murder. (Germany’s privacy laws shield the full names of defendants.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Producer of the Jacksons
description: Barb Lin returns with her sixth New York Times Crossword puzzle.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Barb Lin, she challenged us to a game of pool. In this puzzle, she asks us to recall one of the memorable attributes of a well-known animated character.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Ronald Greene’s Mother Calls for Troopers to Be Charged in His Death
description: Mona Hardin, Mr. Greene’s mother, said a lack of accountability for her son’s death in Louisiana State Police custody in 2019 was “inhumane.”
content: For two years, Mona Hardin has watched with anguish as the state of Louisiana controlled the narrative of how her son Ronald Greene died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brett Berk
title: How Mazda Rode Out the Pandemic While Rivals Slipped
description: Its sales climbed, and it racked up awards for safety and more.
content: The pandemic crushed new-vehicle sales last year in the United States, with behemoths like Ford Motor, General Motors and Honda all posting double-digit sales declines. Altogether, the sales slide reached 15 percent, with under 14.5 million new cars hitting American roads, down from a five-year average of around 17 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: In Rwanda, Macron Tries to Reset Relations With Africa
description: The visit by President Emmanuel Macron of France, and his recognition of the part played by his country in Rwanda’s genocide, reflected his efforts to find friends and potential business partners in Africa.
content: PARIS — After nearly three decades of recriminations over France’s role in Rwanda’s genocide of 1994, the leaders of the two countries on Thursday stood side by side in the Rwandan capital, Kigali, declaring a new chapter in their relations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: E.P.A. to Modify Trump-Era Limits on States’ Ability to Oppose Energy Projects
description: In recent years, states have used the Clean Water Act to block pipelines and other fossil fuel projects. The Trump administration tried to curb that power.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday said it planned to revise a Trump-era rule that limited the ability of states and tribes to veto pipelines and other energy projects that could pollute their local waterways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Madden
title: The ‘Talking’ Dog of TikTok
description: Bunny, an internet-famous sheepadoodle, has brought attention to a new area of study within animal cognition: the use of assistive technology for language acquisition.
content: Alexis Devine said that she knew early on that Bunny, her sheepadoodle puppy, was destined to talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Azzopardi
title: ‘Dog Gone Trouble’ Review: New Dog, Same Tricks
description: A pampered dog finds himself on the streets in this routine animated comedy.
content: Home is at the center of “Dog Gone Trouble,” about a lost pooch whose owner has just died. But this Netflix animated family feature is nothing to write home about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden’s Budget Sees Low Inflation, Rising Debt and Slow Economic Growth
description: The proposal sheds new light on President Biden’s economic agenda and underscores the administration’s belief that the country’s fiscal situation is manageable.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s $6 trillion budget proposal represents the largest increase in federal spending since World War II and offers the most detailed look to date of the White House’s economic priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Ugly N.B.A. Fan Behavior Is Back With Popcorn Toss and Spitting Incident
description: Inappropriate behavior by fans toward Washington’s Russell Westbrook and Atlanta’s Trae Young has highlighted a pitfall in the return to packed arenas for the playoffs.
content: After months of basketballs echoing in nearly empty venues because of the coronavirus pandemic, Barclays Center is rocking, Madison Square Garden is electric and fans packing into N.B.A. arenas across the country are adding a dimension of excitement to playoff games that was sorely lacking in last postseason’s bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: A Sense of Belonging: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
description: Six novels feature characters who hunger for connection so strongly that they transform their environments.
content: Assembling columns is often an exercise in serendipity. For this one, I looked for works I thought would be wildly different from one another: a collection of short stories in translation, a debut about a single consciousness in multiple bodies, a young-adult techno-thriller, an Antarctic ghost story. But I was surprised to find, as I read my way through them, that they explored similar themes: adoption and child-rearing, intergenerational traumas, and characters who hunger for connection, communion and belonging so powerfully that they transform their environments, on scales ranging from the municipal to the cosmic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Broad Coalition of Democrats Presses Biden to Expand Medicare
description: Over 150 House Democrats are pushing the president to include a plan in his infrastructure package to lower the eligibility age, expand benefits and negotiate drug prices.
content: WASHINGTON — A broad coalition of Democrats from across the ideological spectrum plans on Thursday to begin what it promises will be a noisy and sustained campaign to pressure President Biden to include a major expansion of Medicare in his infrastructure package.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do on Memorial Day Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: In 2005, Zaq Landsberg created a new nation in rural Utah called Zaqistan, on the premise that our ideals around governance were worth re-evaluating. In Harlem’s Morningside Park, his yearlong installation “Reclining Liberty” — a 25-foot-long Buddha-like version of the Statue of Liberty — is another re-examination, this time of a quintessential American symbol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: G.O.P. Rivals Trade Insults in Chaotic N.Y.C. Mayoral Debate
description: Curtis Sliwa, the founder of the Guardian Angels, and Fernando Mateo, a restaurateur, yelled at each other repeatedly during the free-wheeling virtual debate.
content: They fought over almost everything, hurled insults back and forth and caused so much general chaos that both had their microphones cut off at different times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels and Natalie Proulx
title: Teaching About the Tulsa Race Massacre With The New York Times
description: In this lesson, students will explore a 3-D model of historical Greenwood — home of “Black Wall Street” — and then learn about how a white mob destroyed a prosperous Black community 100 years ago.
content: Featured Article: “What the Tulsa Race Massacre Destroyed”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lionel Shriver Warns Readers Not to Meet Their Favorite Authors
description: “The warts-and-all version is almost always a disappointment, and they risk a retroactive taint.”
content: “The warts-and-all version is almost always a disappointment, and they risk a retroactive taint,” says the novelist, whose forthcoming book is “Should We Stay or Should We Go.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’ Onstage. A Nightmare Off It.
description: Shakespeare’s Globe survived Elizabethan plagues. Today’s version got through the coronavirus pandemic, but tough times lie ahead.
content: LONDON — At the Globe theater in London one recent Thursday was a sight Shakespeare could have related to: 11 actors larking about onstage rehearsing “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” while beneath them stood the director Sean Holmes, looking furious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman
title: N.Y.C. Lawmakers Take Dramatic Step to Stem Homelessness
description: The City Council voted overwhelmingly to increase a housing subsidy in hopes of making thousands of apartments affordable to people who are homeless or facing eviction.
content: For nearly a decade, New York City has struggled to help homeless people find apartments of their own, as rents hovered in the stratosphere and the number of people stuck in shelters surged past 60,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s featured listings are a four-bedroom house in Chappaqua, N.Y., and a four-bedroom house in Edgewater, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Naomi Osaka Says She Won’t Talk to Journalists at the French Open
description: Citing mental health concerns, the world No. 2 wrote on Instagram Wednesday that she will accept any fines levied for not making herself available to reporters.
content: Naomi Osaka, the four-time Grand Slam singles champion, announced Wednesday that she will not do any news conferences at the French Open because she said they can too often be damaging to the mental health of tennis players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Man Rescued in Colorado Mountain Pass Is Accused in 1982 Murders
description: Alan Lee Phillips was rescued from a snowdrift in 1982 after he signaled SOS with his headlights. The police now say he became trapped on the road after killing two women.
content: On a January night in 1982, Alan Lee Phillips was found shivering in his pickup, stuck in a snowdrift on a treacherous mountain pass in central Colorado.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Cumming-Bruce
title: U.N. Rights Council Orders Inquiry Into Israel After Gaza Strife
description: Acting in the aftermath of the fighting in Gaza, a United Nations panel in Geneva approved a far-ranging inquiry into Israel’s actions.
content: GENEVA — Spurred by the latest fighting in Gaza, the United Nations’ top human rights body voted Thursday to appoint a commission of inquiry with unusually broad latitude to investigate possible war crimes and other abuses committed in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories. Israel denounced the decision as a one-sided sham.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Manson
title: The Catholic Church’s Reproductive Fight Is About Controlling Women’s Freedom
description: It's time to take a look at the role religion plays in American law and jurisprudence.
content: Last summer, after years of excruciating menstrual pain and anemia caused by excessive bleeding, I saw a gynecological specialist. He ordered an M.R.I., suspecting the cause was endometriosis. I instinctively grab my rosary when I’m anxious. For days after the test, I moved bead to bead, praying that the radiologist would find signs of disease so that I could find appropriate treatment. But the test showed a perfectly healthy uterus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Treading a Fragile Line, the Olympics Inch Forward
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, May 27, 2021.
content: “No one can look at Simone Biles doing her flips and not think, ‘I want to watch her do that in Tokyo.’ We’ve got two months left. What can we do to make it safer?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M. will restart several plants idled by the global chip shortage.
description: Production will resume at four factories in North America: one in Michigan, one in Canada and two in Mexico. G.M. shares jumped on the news.
content: General Motors said on Thursday that it would restart four North American plants that had been idled for much of the last four months because of the global shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden says he will release the results of an inquiry into the virus’ origin.
description: An initial report was expected to be completed in three months’ time but officials said work is likely to continue for longer.
content: President Biden said Thursday he expected to release the results of an intelligence report on the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, even as administration officials said the inquiry was likely to extend beyond the initial 90-day deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Investigating the lab leak theory.
content: In the still-early process of investigating the origins of the novel coronavirus, the two most vocal poles of the argument are natural spillover vs. laboratory leak. Virologists still largely lean toward spillover, but the “lab leak” theory is now getting a lot of attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino and Najim Rahim
title: A Wave of Afghan Surrenders to the Taliban Picks Up Speed
description: Dozens of besieged outposts or bases, and four district centers, have given up to the insurgents this month, in an accelerating rural collapse as American troops leave.
content: MEHTARLAM, Afghanistan — Ammunition was depleted inside the bedraggled outposts in Laghman Province. Food was scarce. Some police officers hadn’t been paid in five months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: The Hong Kong police, citing the pandemic, block Tiananmen anniversary events.
description: The city has recorded just 24 infections over the past two weeks. It is the second straight year that the authorities have blocked the memorial observances.
content: The Hong Kong police, citing the continuing threat of the coronavirus, rejected a request to hold a march and candlelight vigil to remember those killed in the 1989 crackdown on the Tiananmen protest, event organizers said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Janet Yellen says the Treasury needs more funds to oversee the economic recovery.
description: The Treasury secretary called on Congress to provide more funding for her agency, which oversees a sprawling set of relief programs.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen warned on Thursday that her agency lacked sufficient resources to oversee an economic recovery that still has “a long road ahead” and called on Congress to provide her with more funds to oversee a sprawling set of relief programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Swansburg
title: Game On! Great New Sports Books
description: Just in time for summer, these titles offer a variety of surprises — like the members of the 1986 Boston Red Sox discussing their famous collapse and Kevin Garnett offering his prescriptions for success.
content: Wenham, Mass., is a genteel hamlet north of Boston, home to horse farms and a venerable teahouse. Just down the road, the Myopia Hunt Club hosts polo on Sundays; John Updike golfed there. The Red Sox reliever Bob Stanley lived in Wenham. One day in 1986, Stanley’s children, aged 4 and 5 at the time, were playing in the driveway when an unfamiliar car pulled up. The driver emerged, picked up one of the kids’ bicycles and hurled it at a basketball hoop. Before peeling away, the stranger implored the children: “Tell your father he sucks!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Yes, Steinbeck Wrote a Werewolf Novel. Don’t Expect to Read It.
description: A scholar of American literature at Stanford says it’s worth publishing. The agents representing the Steinbeck estate strongly disagree.
content: Nine years before John Steinbeck published his Pulitzer Prize-winning historical masterpiece, “The Grapes of Wrath,” he was working on a lighthearted detective novel featuring a werewolf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Moby Doc’ Review: He Understands How He’s an Unlikely Pop Star
description: The movie is directed by Robert Gordon Bralver, but it’s a late-life self-realization project for the musician.
content: In “Moby Doc,” animation, staged dream sequences, skits and archival footage form a portrait of the title artist, the musician Moby. While the credited director is Robert Gordon Bralver, the movie is clearly a late-life self-realization project for Moby himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Christina Goldbaum
title: How the Candidates for N.Y.C. Mayor Plan to Improve Transit
description: Eight leading mayoral candidates share their ideas and plans for public transit.
content: When the pandemic engulfed New York, it highlighted the vital role public transit plays in a city where essential workers — many of whom are poor and people of color — count on the subway and buses to get around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘A Quiet Place Part II’ Review: Pump Up the Volume
description: This sequel to John Krasinski’s alien-invasion blockbuster is brasher, louder and less focused than its predecessor.
content: Movies need endings, but franchises need cliffhangers, and “A Quiet Place Part II” is emblematic of this problem. The first “A Quiet Place” (2018) gave us a beautifully tragic finale, one that emphasized the story’s core themes of human resilience and familial devotion. It was almost perfect, and it could have been enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Falih Hassan
title: Iraq Arrests Militia Leader, Inciting a Standoff With Iran-Backed Forces
description: The arrest of an Iranian-backed paramilitary leader in the killing of government protesters enraged powerful militias in Iraq and posed a test of the prime minister’s pledge to rein them in.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s leader has been under intense pressure to rein in the dozens of paramilitary groups that are nominally under the command of the Iraqi government but have proved seemingly impossible for him to control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: Mysterious Disappearances, Jewel Heists and Creepy Babysitters
description: Truth is definitely stranger than fiction in this summer’s crop of true-crime books.
content: Fifty years ago, on a hot summer night in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, an 18-year-old named Paula Oberbroeckling borrowed a car that belonged to her roommate, Debbie, and promised to be back soon. She never returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Plan B’ Review: A Joy Ride in Search of Emergency Contraception
description: Two teenagers embark on a madcap road trip to Planned Parenthood in this comedy from Natalie Morales.
content: In the endearing comedy “Plan B,” Sunny (Kuhoo Verma) and Lupe (Victoria Moroles) are teenage best friends, bonded by hormonal longings and their will to sneak around their strict but loving parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller
title: ‘He is the hero.’ A San Jose survivor says a call from one of the victims saved his life.
description: “There are still people out there who want to help others more than themselves,” said Sukhvir Singh, who received a warning about the shooting from one of his slain colleagues.
content: The phone call came at 6:36 a.m. and lasted for 44 seconds. Sukhvir Singh, a mechanic at the rail yard where nine of his colleagues were killed, says the call on Wednesday morning was the difference between life and death for him and a half dozen co-workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Park
title: How Do You Illustrate Anguish? With Rage or Silence?
description: In his latest Graphic Content column, Ed Park looks at Barry Windsor-Smith’s “Monsters” and Margaret Kimball’s “And Now I Spill the Family Secrets.”
content: For this column, I’ve written in the past about Chris Ware’s “Rusty Brown” (356 pages, 18 years in the making, and weighing in at 3.5 pounds), Seth’s “Clyde Fans” (478 pages, 20 years, 3.15 pounds) and Jason Lutes’s “Berlin” (580, 22, 3.8). Add to the list MONSTERS (Fantagraphics, $39.99, 4.1 pounds), a 35-year labor by the British cartoonist Barry Windsor-Smith, and you have nearly a century’s worth of cartooning in just four books. For 365 large-format, black-and-white pages, Windsor-Smith conveys gruesome body horror and tender family scenes, nightmarish doom and quiet moments of connection. What starts off in the viscera-rich world of the gory EC comics of the ’50s morphs into a subtle exploration of memory, as the monster of the book’s title escapes from the lab, treks to his childhood home and listens to ghosts re-enact the tragedy of his youth for over 100 pages. Then things get really twisted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Novak Djokovic and Ashleigh Barty Are Top Seeds at the French Open
description: Djokovic, Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal, who is a heavy favorite to win for the 14th time in Paris, are all in the top half of the draw. Naomi Osaka is the No. 2 seed and Serena Williams No. 7.
content: Rafael Nadal, the 13-time French Open champion who is seeking a fifth consecutive title at Roland Garros beginning Sunday, bears an ill-fitting label in the men’s singles draw this year: the No. 3 seed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aruna D'Souza
title: Nina Katchadourian’s Eccentric Existentialism
description: In her first show at Pace, an artist driven by curiosity and a penchant for the absurd tries to understand the world. The results are touching and sometimes hilarious.
content: Nina Katchadourian is a sculptor, a printmaker, a photographer, a performance artist, a video artist, a sound artist — but more than any of those things she is an artist with a voracious curiosity and a marathoner’s stamina when it comes to running with an idea. In her first show at Pace Gallery, “Cumulus,” she offers up seven projects that are witty, sometimes even guffaw-inducing. But don’t let that fool you: Underneath the playfulness lurk some pretty fundamental questions about how we organize knowledge to make sense of our past and present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kreda
title: With Fans in Full Voice, Islanders Upset Penguins
description: The Islanders won three consecutive games, including two at home, to advance to the second round. They had their first series-clinching victory at Nassau Coliseum since 1993.
content: The Islanders arrived at Nassau Coliseum on Wednesday with the opportunity to clinch a playoff series victory at their original home for the first time since 1993.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Walter Kissinger, Businessman and Brother of Henry, Dies at 96
description: Walter shed his Bavarian accent, while Henry notably did not. Asked why he lost his, Walter told interviewers, “Because I am the Kissinger who listens.”
content: Walter Kissinger, who was a successful businessman and philanthropist on Long Island and who for much of his adult life had to contend with being the lesser-known Kissinger — that is, not the secretary of state — died on May 3 at his home in San Rafael, Calif. He was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Sheriff: The gunman was ‘very deliberate, very fast.’
description: Investigators do not yet know whether the victims of Wednesday’s shooting at a rail yard in San Jose were specifically targeted, and they have not identified a motive for the gunman, Laurie Smith, the sheriff of Santa Clara County, said in an interview Thursday morning on NBC’s “Today.”
content: Investigators do not yet know whether the victims of Wednesday’s shooting at a rail yard in San Jose were specifically targeted, and they have not identified a motive for the gunman, Laurie Smith, the sheriff of Santa Clara County, said in an interview Thursday morning on NBC’s “Today.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: At His Moment of Triumph, Arthur Jafa Is Looking for Trouble
description: With a survey in Europe and stark new sculptures in New York, he is bringing to the fore darker, more personal themes. “I’m an undertaker,” he said. “I don’t do the uplift thing.”
content: In 2019, Arthur Jafa won the Golden Lion award for best artist in the Venice Biennale for “The White Album.” A collage of found and original video, it mapped the psychology of Black-white relations in America today — the brutality, awkwardness and sometimes care. “Just as the film critiques a moment fraught with violence, in tenderly portraying the artist’s friends and family, it also speaks to our capacity for love,” the jury concluded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Trussoni
title: Summer Reads Guaranteed to Make Your Heart Thump and Your Skin Crawl
description: If your idea of a beach read involves abject terror, we’ve got some new novels to recommend.
content: I survived my first horror films at slumber parties. There would be five or six girls camped out in sleeping bags before a TV set, clinging to each other, wet-the-bed terrified. This collective experience of horror created a strong bond between us. It was the 12-year-old-girl version of going to war: If we could make it through the Chucky franchise, we could make it through anything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Rush Limbaugh’s time slot is being filled as competition for his fans heats up.
description: When he died in February, Mr. Limbaugh had an audience of about 15 million listeners.
content: Three months after the death of the right-wing talk radio star Rush Limbaugh, Premiere Networks announced that Clay Travis and Buck Sexton would take over his time slot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: To Test Covid Protocols, Cruise Lines Turn to Volunteer Guinea Pigs
description: Hundreds of thousands of cruise lovers have signed up to take part in sailings designed to test new health and safety measures.
content: Since March of last year, cruise ships carrying more than 250 people have been prohibited by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention from sailing in U.S. waters. To start again, they need to follow a complex process that, in some cases, involves simulated cruises designed to test Covid-19 protocols. Hundreds of thousands of frustrated and restless cruise fans have lined up to be guinea pigs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: “Mare of Easttown” ends and “Meerkat Manor” returns. To everything there is a season.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for the Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Apocalypse ’45’ Review: Graphic Images of Wartime
description: Candid testimonies from World War II veterans accompanies vivid archival footage in this immersive documentary that showcases the myths we tell ourselves about war.
content: At one point in “Apocalypse ’45,” the camera gazes over Tokyo from an American military bomber as the plane ejects a cluster of cylinders. For several beats, the bombs disappear into the air. Then we see the explosions: tiny bursts of orange far below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: In Australia, Births of Tasmanian Devils Are a Milestone After 3,000 Years
description: Seven babies were born in the semi-wild of a nature preserve, millenniums after the animals were wiped out on the Australian mainland. Whether they can survive is another question.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Pink, hairless, deaf and blind, the roughly month-old joeys were but the size of a shelled peanut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Fielder’s Choice? Cubs Turn a Simple Grounder Into a Wild Run.
description: With a wily bit of baserunning, Javier Baez confounded Pittsburgh’s infield, allowing a run to score. The Pirates could have just touched first.
content: Baseball’s long history has allowed ample opportunity for wackiness. It is, after all, a sport in which the coaches wear the same outfits as the players, the action runs counterclockwise and stealing is not only legal, it is encouraged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: A surge of cases in Malaysia is partly linked to prayer gatherings.
description: With more new infections per capita than almost anywhere else in Asia, the country reimposed restrictions as the prime minister called on Malaysians to observe “a self-lockdown.”
content: Malaysia on Wednesday recorded nearly 7,500 coronavirus cases and 63 deaths, its highest tolls since the pandemic began, and has joined several other Southeast Asian nations in introducing new restrictions to curb a resurgence of infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden is said to be planning to nominate Burns and Garcetti for ambassadorships.
description: The president has also selected Thomas R. Nides, Rahm Emanuel and Ken Salazar for posts, according to people familiar with the process.
content: President Biden plans to announce that he has selected R. Nicholas Burns, a veteran Foreign Service officer and a former ambassador to NATO, as his ambassador to China, and Mayor Eric Garcetti of Los Angeles as his ambassador to India, according to two people familiar with the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: A Cap on Friends?
description: How many friends can one person realistically have? Weigh in on what a recent research study shows.
content: In a 1993 study, Robin Dunbar, a British anthropologist, theorized that humans could have no more than about 150 meaningful relationships, a measure that became known as Dunbar’s number.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A lockdown in Victoria State, Australia, follows a variant-fueled outbreak.
description: After nearly three months without an infection, health officials have found 26 cases in the Melbourne area. Critics blamed ill-equipped quarantine facilities and a slow vaccine rollout.
content: The state of Victoria, Australia, announced a seven-day lockdown beginning Thursday night to stem a coronavirus outbreak in the northern suburbs of Melbourne, the country’s second-most populous city, after Sydney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: The Future Is Velvet Ropes
description: If digital-world nightclubs get harder to access, we risk missing out on new ideas.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Howard University Renames College of Fine Arts After Chadwick Boseman
description: The actress and alumna Phylicia Rashad will serve as dean, and Robert A. Iger, the Walt Disney Company’s executive chairman, will lead fund-raising efforts to build a new facility.
content: Howard University will name its newly re-established College of Fine Arts in honor of the actor and alumnus Chadwick Boseman, university officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wall Street chiefs testified before Congress.
description: The chief executives of the six biggest American lenders testified before the House Committee on Financial Services on Thursday, for the first time since 2019.
content: The chief executives of the six biggest American lenders testified before the House Committee on Financial Services on Thursday, for the first time since 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Betnijah Laney Is the Scoring Threat the Liberty Needed
description: Laney has scored at least 20 points in the first six games of the season, the first Liberty player ever to do so. She was the team’s leading scorer in four of its five victories.
content: Athletes generally improve on fairly predictable trajectories. A role player at age 24 may have some upside, but probably isn’t going to suddenly become a superstar at 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Biden’s Silence on Abortion Rights at a Key Moment Worries Liberals
description: As a case before the Supreme Court threatens Roe v. Wade and Democrats’ urgency grows, many activists believe the president needs to be bolder in defending reproductive rights.
content: State legislatures have introduced more than 500 restrictions on abortion over the past four months, a huge increase from previous years. The Supreme Court plans to take up a case that could weaken or even overturn the constitutional right to abortion enshrined nearly a half-century ago in Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Mercy of the Jungle’ Review: Soldiers Lost Among the Enemy
description: In this immersive portrait of ethnic conflict by the Rwandan filmmaker Joel Karekezi, two men also take on the jungle and the savage elements.
content: Set in Kivu, at the eastern edge of the Democratic Republic of Congo, “The Mercy of the Jungle” wrings existential dread from its immersive conceit, following a pair of Rwandan soldiers swept up in the haze of multinational and regional conflicts that broke out in the late 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Colman Domingo’s Crooked Summer
description: He’s proud to have appeared in, and championed, films that show off Black men at their soulful best. His roles in “Candyman” and “Zola” are different.
content: Colman Domingo — actor, playwright, dramaturge, producer, professor and the fella who showed up to this year’s Oscars in a hot pink sequined Versace suit — is likely best known for his character of Victor on television’s “Fear the Walking Dead.” He’s also brought a sensitive soulfulness to the array of characters he’s portrayed in some of the past decade’s most prominent Black films: “The Butler,” “Selma,” “42,” “The Birth of a Nation,” “If Beale Street Could Talk” and “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: A Funny Thing Happened While Researching Algorithms
description: Carrington Moore signed up for a dating app to better understand user preferences for a start-up business. Then he came across Schnelle Shelby’s profile.
content: Carrington Moore never liked the idea of online dating. In the summer of 2014, though, joining Match all of a sudden became a professional obligation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lillian Guerra
title: The Return of Cuba’s Security State
description: Today words, ideas and a commitment to peaceful protest are no less powerful threats to the Cuban state.
content: The Cuban performance artist Luis Manuel Otero Alcántara’s home in San Isidro, one of Old Havana’s poor and majority-Black barrios, lies steps away from Cuba’s National Archive and the childhood home of José Martí, Cuba’s exalted 19th-century hero and fighter for racial justice. The promises of history and the grinding realities of life after 62 years of Communist rule collide in San Isidro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Economy Is Spinning Its Wheels, and About to Take Off
description: The bad news is a byproduct of extraordinary good news.
content: You’re driving to an appointment, but you’re running late, and you’re stuck at a red light. Being a law-abiding citizen, you won’t run the light, but you floor the gas pedal the second it changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: QAnon Now as Popular in U.S. as Some Major Religions, Poll Suggests
description: Fifteen percent of Americans believe that “patriots may have to resort to violence” to restore the country’s rightful order, the poll indicated.
content: As hopes fade for a bipartisan inquiry into the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, it’s increasingly clear that the Republican base remains in thrall to the web of untruths spun by Donald J. Trump — and perhaps even more outlandish lies, beyond those of the former president’s making.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden to Propose $6 Trillion Budget to Make U.S. More Competitive
description: The president’s plans to invest in infrastructure, education, health care and more would push federal spending to its highest sustained levels since World War II.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden will propose a $6 trillion budget on Friday that would take the United States to its highest sustained levels of federal spending since World War II as he looks to fund a sweeping economic agenda that includes large new investments in education, transportation and fighting climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tzipi Livni
title: There Is a Solution to the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: A two-state solution remains our only viable option.
content: TEL AVIV — The first meetings of peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian Authority back in 2007 were very emotional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Is Jake Tapper for Sale?
description: The CNN anchor discusses how the streaming wars might change the news business and why he won’t let liars on his show.
content: AT&T owns CNN — for now. But one day Netflix and Apple could be in a bidding war for the CNN anchor Jake Tapper. That’s Kara Swisher’s take, anyway. It could be the next step in the streaming wars, and a natural evolution for an increasingly personality-driven cable news business that is under pressure to compete with the 24/7 engagement — and enragement — of social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaya Laterman
title: A Bright Spot for Small Businesses: Deals on Manhattan Rents
description: Commercial landlords are negotiating, and many entrepreneurs see this as the perfect time to expand.
content: Last spring, when Stacey Fraser was forced to close all four locations of her children’s clothing store Pink Chicken because of the pandemic, the thought of firing her tight-knit group of 14 employees, let alone losing her business, was devastating. She spent much of the shutdown crying, losing sleep and watching Netflix.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Subway Swabbers Find a Microbe Jungle and Thousands of New Species
description: A team of international researchers has assembled an atlas of microorganisms present in 60 cities around the world.
content: For centuries, naturalists have mapped the world’s flora and fauna. They have assembled atlases of migratory birds and cold-water fishes, sketched out the geography of carnivorous animals and alpine plants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia Rejects Some Flight Plans, as Belarus Grows More Isolated
description: The skies over Eastern Europe became a geopolitical checkerboard, and a Swiss email provider pushed back against Belarus’s claims of an emailed bomb threat.
content: MOSCOW — The airspace over Eastern Europe turned into a geopolitical checkerboard on Thursday, as Russia rejected some European flights that were avoiding Belarus, the latest salvo in the furor over the forced landing of a passenger jet with a Belarusian dissident onboard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Showbiz Books for Summer
description: New titles — about Lorraine Hansberry, “Midnight Cowboy” and more — get to the heart of our enduring obsessions with Hollywood and the performing arts.
content: Long before he became the celebrated filmmaker of “Sunset Boulevard,” “Some Like It Hot” and “The Apartment,” a young Billy Wilder worked briefly as a dancer for hire in the ballroom of a fashionable Berlin hotel. As he described the endeavor — one that called for a certain amount of imagination and role-playing in its own right — for a German newspaper in 1927, “This is no easy way to earn your daily bread, nor is it the kind that sentimental, softhearted types can stomach. But others can live from it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Oklahoma Attorney General Resigns, Citing ‘Personal Matters’
description: Attorney General Mike Hunter announced his resignation one day after The Oklahoman said it had sent him questions about an extramarital affair.
content: Attorney General Mike Hunter of Oklahoma announced his resignation on Wednesday, a day after a local newspaper said it had questioned him about an extramarital affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Shimabukuro
title: A Protest Moment I’ll Never Forget
description: Last year, more than 30 Times reporters across the country covered the demonstrations after George Floyd’s death. Here, 10 of them reflect on the sights and interactions that have stayed with them.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Kay Tobin Lahusen, Gay Rights Activist and Photographer, Dies at 91
description: She and her partner, Barbara Gittings, were on the front lines long before Stonewall, and Ms. Lahusen photographed protests during the movement’s earliest days.
content: Kay Tobin Lahusen, a prominent gay rights activist whose photographs documented the movement’s earliest days and depicted lesbians who were out when they were virtually absent from popular culture, died on Wednesday in West Chester, Pa. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate Poised to Pass $195 Billion Bill to Bolster Competitiveness With China
description: The legislation, which has bipartisan support, would be the first major industrial policy effort in decades.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday was on the brink of passing expansive legislation to ramp up research and development into scientific innovation, advancing what would be the government’s first significant foray into industrial policy in decades in a bid to bolster competitiveness against China.

content: We have three adult children. Our middle son planned to be married last November, but the wedding was postponed for a year because of the pandemic. Recently we met him, his fiancée and his future in-laws in Florida, where the couple surprised us with a tiny beach wedding — just parents and one best friend. Trying to be inclusive, I sent a picture of the ceremony to my other two children. Rather than feeling joy for their brother, though, they were angry at being excluded and unaware of the wedding. (They both live thousands of miles away, and the large wedding postponed until this November is still on!) Further discussion has only led to more anger. author: By Matt Wolf
title: Claylike Models and Beamed Actors: London Theater Is Back, in Unusual Ways
description: One “play” uses only voice-overs. Another features a main actor only on video. And under Covid rules, an 11-person Shakespeare cast counts as an army.
content: LONDON — Theaters here are gradually reopening for business, but not in ways you might expect. Take the astonishing 45-minute installation at the Bridge Theater, “Flight.” A story of Afghan refugees crossing Europe to start a new life, this collaboration between the directors Candice Edmunds and Jamie Harrison uses diminutive claylike figures in revolving boxes to chart the journey of two boys, Kabir (a plaintive Nalini Chetty) and Aryan (Farshid Rokey), from Kabul to London.
source.name: The New York Times
